The entire time of the faculty
and many of the students of the
geologieal department during the
past summer and early fall has
been taken up in work connected
with the war. Prior to his death,
Dr. W. B. Clark, former State geologist of Maryland, was at work
on a report on the road materials
to be found locally which were
suitable for the construction of
emergency roads along the entire
Atlantic Coast. Dr. E. B. Mathews, State geologist of Maryland,
as sub-chairman of the Research
Committee of the National Council
of Defense has energetically carried on this work.
The report is composed of facts
gathered in each of the States,
from Maine to Texas, by local geologists and highway engineers. It
contains a digest of knowledge
covering conditions of road construction, sources of road material
and the available road machinery
and men trained in road engineering in the several States.
In studying the sources of road
material, the several authors have
prepared maps showing not only
the quarry sites and ledges, but
also the stone walls and rock piles
which might be used in an emergency for building roads. When
completed, the report will present
a more complete and extensive
summary of conditions for highway construction than any which
has been issued. The investigation, when completed, will be deposited with the War College of
the Army.
Members of the Geological Survey staff have also been preparing
general and special reports on the
water resources of Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia,
making special reports on the underground water conditions at
Camp Meade and other sites in
which the Army and Navy Departments are interested. This
work has been chiefly in charge of
Dr. Mathews and Associate Professor E. W. Berry.
Dr. H. F. Reid, after returning
from the western front in July,
was occupied with preparing his
report to the National Research
Council and in making his recommendations to the Federal authorities. Later he investigated the
peculiarities of the compass used
in aeroplanes.

Johns Hopkins has been allotted a maximum quota of twentyfour men to be assigned on the
recommendation of President
Goodnow to the Officers' Reserve
Training Camps opening next
January.
The personnel of the January
camps is to be composed primarily
of men selected from the various
branches of the service. The colleges and universities having good
military standing will, however,
all receive an allotment of appointments, each to be made on the
recommendation of the president
of the institution.
The men appointed must have
had at least one year of military
training in addition to possessing
the qualifications required of entrants in the former training
camps. In view of the stringency
of the requirements it is improbable that the full quota allotted
to Johns Hopkins will be made
up. In order to preserve the good
military standing of the University, only men in whose success
President Goodnow has every confidence will be recommended. It
is very probable that some of the
enlisted men now attending the
University on furlough will be
among those appointed.
Speaking last Saturday with regard to the formation.of the Hopkins corps, Captain Guild stated
that the present arrangement of
three companies would hold unless
a fairly permanent personnel of
such size as to fully guarantee the
formation of an additional company should be found to exist.
Captain Guild considers the formation of a new company on anything except a permanent basis
highly undesirable.
Arrangements as a result of
which the members of the Hopkins
corps are to present a consistent
and soldierly appearance are
rapidly nearing completion. The
details of the uniform have now
been fully decided upon, and show
many improvement and additions
over last year. The Hopkins uniform will have two distinctive features. By order of the War Department a bronze seal of the University will be worn on the collar.
In addition, the members of the
corps will wear a small silver University seal on the campaign hat.
A large proportion of the men
have adopted the sheepskin lined
military half-coat, and in all probability it will become part of the
regular equipment of all members
of the battalion.

By COACH BRENNICK
The opening of the football season found conditions at Johns
Hopkins in precisely the same
status as at the other prominent
universities—the older men of the
upper classes had joined the various branches of the Army and
Navy with the result that the team
of necessity had to be constructed
in the main from new material or
from slightly experienced material. The consequence is that we
have a younger, lighter and more
inexperienced team than usual;
indeed, one of the outstanding features of the games thus far played
has been the comparative youthfulness of the Hopkins team as
compared with its opponents.
This is by no means a cause of
regret, but rather is an indication
of the manner in which the eligible
men of the University responded
to the call to the colors. In the
Brown game five freshmen participated, viz.: Jones, Carey, Katencamp, Rouse and Gould. Another
feature worthy of note is that by
far the major portion of the squad
is composed of undergraduates,for
it was decided that no effort on
the part of the athletic authorities or of any other persons was
to be exerted to have the medical
students play on the team. Four
men from this school have come
out, but they are coming out quite
of their own volition and because
they desire in this manner to secure their recreation.
The squad, which now numbers
about thirty-two men, has shown
thus far a very lively interest and
spirit; it is perhaps fair to say
that it is the most spirited team
that has represented the University in some years. The men realize that they are permitted to
play at all simply because the governmental and University authorities feel that a combative sport
such as is football is an excellent
training for a man who may be
called later to fight for his country. The training of the squad is,
quite naturally, subordinated to
military drill, so for this reason
no practice is held at all on Mondays, while on other afternoons
individuals of the squad perform
their military duties according to
their scheduled assignments.

The Glee Club held its first rehearsal on Wednesday evening, October 17, which was attended by

DATE SET FOR CLASS DEBATE
Senior-Junior Debate and Adams Medal
Contest on December 14—Council
Arranging Triangular and
Other Debates.

The Debating Council met for
the first time this year in Dr.
John C. French's office on Monday, October 15, and after completing its organization adopted tentative plans for the work of
the coming year. Dr. French, the
faculty adviser of the Council, was
present at the meeting.
Frank Morley, Jr., '18, was
elected to fill the vacancy of senior
delegate occasioned by the resignation of Stanley I. Clark, who is
now a sergeant in the Hopkins ambulance unit at Allentown, Pa.
Morley formerly attended Haverford College, and is a son of Dr.
Morley, professor of mathematics
at the University. Charles H. Miegel, '19, was elected secretary of
the Council.
The secretary was instructed to
get in immediate communication
with the Universities of Virginia
and North Carolina, to definitely
find out whether they intend to resume the annual triangular debate. The triangular debate has
been the annual debating classic
for some years past, but was indefinitely postponed last year on
account of war preparations. It
is hoped that Virginia and North
Carolina will decide to continue
the system which has been so uniformly successful and satisfactory.
The date for the senior-junior
debate has been moved up to Friday, December 14, in order that
more time may be given to intercollegiate debating. The subject •
for this debate will be announced
within a week or two, and try-outs
will be held soon after. The
Adams prize is awarded to the
winning team. The Adams medal
contest for public speaking, open
only to members of the Class of
1920; will take place at the same
time.
Charles Leber, '20, was appointed to investigate and report on the
possibility of a freshman-sophomore debate and a freshman debating team. If sufficient men
among the under classmen are interested, the class debate would be
arranged to take place immediately before or after the Christmas
vacation, and debates would be
arranged with the freshmen of
other colleges.
There is a trip to Washington
pending, and it is probable that
the clubs will repeat their last
year's concert at Tome.
Rehearsals are held either Wednesday or Thursday evenings at
2115 North Charles street. and in
view of the splendid outlook everyone who is at all musically inclined is urged to be at the next
rehearsal, Thursday evening, October 25, at 7.45 o'clock.

Dr. John C. French has been

The system adopted by the Bureau

register at the Bureau and specify
the work he prefers to undertake.
Subsequently, when any requests
come to the University for men,the
director resorts to the register and
picks the man for the job.
The main purpose of the Bureau
is to secure teaching positions for
graduates. Many requests, however, are made for part-time work

class of boys during afternoons,
which position has been held by
Hopkins undergraduates for the
last three years. The Bureau
makes it possible for many Hopkinsmen to earn money while carrying on their college work to help

students desiring positions every

addressed the third and fourth year
students at the Medical School on
Saturday, and Dr. Raney addressed the second and first year
men on Monday with Drs. MacCallum and Sabin, respectively,
presiding. The result of these
meetings was that with practical
unanimity the medical students
pledged one dollar per person to
the project.
This puts the Hopkins quota
well within striking distance of
completion. This quota amounts
for the entire University to $2,500,
and has been divided as follows:
Section I (trustees), $500; Section II (faculty), $500; Section
III (library), $500; Section IV
(library staff), $500; Section V
(students), $500. This last portion is divided equally between the
undergraduates and the medical
students, while Section IV was to
be contributed or collected by the
library staff, drawing upon outside
sources as well as graduate students.
These five sections now stand in
point of collection as follows:
Trustees' section complete; faculty section, $284.50; library section
complete; library staff, $362.35.
The action of the Medical School
students means over-subscription
of their share of the last section,
so that only the undergraduate
share needs now to be pulled up to
the mark. To date they have contributed $73.50. It should be said
that the library staff has nearly
completed collections of $500, but
as a part of this was drawn from
the faculty, it is not credited to
them.

come in from the faculty have
been practically unsolicited, so
that Dr. Ames and Dr. Raney
are just starting now systematically through that list, and this will
presumably be completed by the
end of the week.

The football situation at Hopkins and the duties of every student
• in regard to supporting the team
were most forcefully described by
Coach Brennick at the mass-meeting held last Friday at 12.30
o'clock in the Civil Engineering
Building. The meeting was but
poorly attended, as have been the
other student gatherings this fall.
Alec Wolfe made note of this in his
opening speech, and after a discussion it was decided to hold subsequent mass-meetings on every Friday at 12.30 o'clock, instead of on
Wednesdays.
This arrangement was decided
upon by a committee composed of
one representative of the Student
Council, one of the Athletic Association and one of the Y. M. C. A.
The majority of those present favored Friday as the suitable day.
The particular point made by
Coach Brennick in his speech was
that since the Secretary of War
favors college sports as a means
to prepare men to meet the physical demands of war, it is no longer
the student's privilege, but it is
his duty to come out for football
or some other form of athletics.
He also said that it would be a
good plan for those who for some
valid reason cannot come out for
the 'Varsity team to practice on
Straus Field, and meet local teams
for the sake of the exercise afforded. Those, however, who are qualified to play on the first team and
have not yet donned the J. H. U.
football uniform should join the
squad at once. And all the other
students, he continued,should support the team by rendering it encouragement from the cheering
section. He concluded by saying
that thought the team was crippled
because of injuries sustained by
several members, he expected to
make a good showing against
Dickinson, provided it received
loyal support.

The General Athletic Association of Johns Hopkins University
elected men to fill the vacancies
left by members enlisting in Government service, and chose managers for the lacrosse and baseball
teams at its first meeting of the
year on last Monday. Alec Wolfe,
president of the Association, presided at the fleeting, which was
attended by Dr. Abercrombie,
Harry Corner, graduate manager
of athletics; Dr. "Tom" Brown,
alumni delegate; Jarrett, newlyelected senior delegate; Schmidt
and Carroll, junior delegates; and
Stuart, sophomore delegate.
In accordance with its power to
fill vacancies, it elected D. W.
Burbage vice-president, which office was held by F. Sutton; Beverly Smith, corresponding secretary,
to fill S. Egerton's place; Marion
B. Hopkins, alumni delegate, to
occupy M. Bagley's position; and
Winslow and Jarrett, senior delegates, to supersede Robert Duncan
and E. S. Warner. All these men
are leaders in Hopkins athletics—
Burbage being in charge of cheering; Smith being prominent in
track and Captain Firor's assistalit; Winslow participating in
both football and track; and Jarrett being manager of football.
R. C. Thomsen, '19, was elected
manager of lacrosse, to fill the vacancy left by Clark, now in the
Hopkins ambulance unit, and D.
Coulter,'20, was appointed to take
Randall's place as manager of the
baseball team. Randall is now in
the Maryland field artillery.
Among other matters, it granted
permission to the track team to
use the cross-country course, lockers and field house for a crosscountry run of the S. A. I. A. A.
on November 24, and the A. A. U.
championship run on Thanksgiving Day.

Over thirty men were present at
the organization meeting of the
track team last Thursday noon in
the Civil Engineering Building,
when Captain Firor, Manager Carroll and Coach Joseph T. England
told of. what was expected of the
team, and showed the valuable opportunities opened to those who
turnout • for it. Twenty-four men
expressed their desire at thd close
of the meeting to become members
of the squad.
Captain Firor, who has been connected with the team for several
years and is now a first-year student at the Medical School, welcomed the prospective candidates
and gave in an inspiring speech
the qualifications necessary for a
track man to have, and the physical advantage of the training received. He made _mention of the
fact that loyalty and perseverance
were two qualities necessary for
the candidate to possess. If a
man, however, is not willing to .
work hard and unselfishly for the
team he is not wanted. Firor also
pointed out the unusual chances a
freshman has to make the team
this year.
The manager spoke next on the
schedule, which starts off with
the big cross-country meets—the
S. A. I. A. A. meet on Saturday,
November 24,, and the A. A. U.
championships on Thanksgiving
Day. The contestants will be
started in both these meets at a
time which will cause the finish
to occur in between the halves of
the football games taking place on
those days—the St. John's and
Maryland "Aggies" games, respectively.
It is necessary, therefore, that a
large squad turn out at once for
cross-country work, as it will be
impossible for Hopkins to compete
unless represented by a good team.
Also a large squad is desired in
order to make possible the staging of an interclass track and field
meet at the close of fall training.

It is funny that you have only
received one of my letters, for I
wrote again from Paris at the
same time that I sent a number
of picture postcards. I can't send
any picture postal cards from here
as it is against the law to send
pictures of any kind from the war
zone.
We have been fairly busy lately.
About every other night we have
to stay out until morning. In
fact, most of our real work is at
night. If we drive too near the
lines in day time, the German observation balloons can spot us. It
is easy to trace the lines from the
location of the balloons. Both the
French and Gernians have lines
of observation balloons about two
to four miles back from the
trenches. We seldom go closer to
the trenches than the artillery, but
it gets quite hot there at times.
Twice the other night we had to
stop and wait because the Germans were dropping shells at the
bridges and towns ahead of us.
As soon as they slowed up we
went on.
We are getting so used to hearing the big guns and hearing Boche
shells whistle overhead that we
scarcely notice them any more. It
does not seem very dangerous, although no one knows where he
will happen to be when the shell
lands.

The Debating Council met for
the first time this year in Dr.
John C. French's office on Monday, October 15, and after completing its organization adopted tentative plans for the work of
the coming year. Dr. French, the
faculty adviser of the Council, was
present at the meeting.
Frank Morley, Jr., '18, was
elected to fill the vacancy of senior
delegate occasioned by the resignation of Stanley I. Clark, who is
now a sergeant in the Hopkins ambulance unit at Allentown, Pa.
Morley formerly attended Haverford College, and is a son of Dr.
Morley, professor of mathematics
at the University. Charles H. Miegel, '19, was elected secretary of
the Council.
The secretary was instructed to
get in immediate communication
with the Universities of Virginia
and North Carolina, to definitely
find out whether they intend to resume the annual triangular debate. The triangular debate has
been the annual debating classic
for some years past, but was indefinitely postponed last year on
account of war preparations. It
is hoped that Virginia and North
Carolina will decide to continue
the system which has been so uniformly successful and satisfactory.

debate has been moved up to Friday, December 14, in order that
more time may be given to intercollegiate debating. The subject •
for this debate will be announced
within a week or two, and try-outs
will be held soon after. The
Adams prize is awarded to the
winning team. The Adams medal
contest for public speaking, open

1920; will take place at the same
time.

Dr. John C. French has been
appointed to succeed Dr. Magoffin, now a captain in the Quartermaster's Corps, as director of the
Hopkins Bureau of Appointments.
The system adopted by the Bureau
works something like this: Any
alumnus, graduate student or undergraduate of the University may
register at the Bureau and specify
the work he prefers to undertake.
Subsequently, when any requests
come to the University for men,the
director resorts to the register and
picks the man for the job.
The main purpose of the Bureau
is to secure teaching positions for
graduates. Many requests, however, are made for part-time work
which may be undertaken by undergraduates. Recently a local private school has asked for an athletic director to take charge of a
class of boys during afternoons,
which position has been held by
Hopkins undergraduates for the
last three years. The Bureau
makes it possible for many Hopkinsmen to earn money while carrying on their college work to help
pay their expenses.

students desiring positions every
day in Room 303 at 12.30 o'clock.

unanimity the medical students

the project.

be contributed or collected by the
library staff, drawing upon outside
sources as well as graduate students.

point of collection as follows:

complete; library staff, $362.35.
The action of the Medical School
students means over-subscription
of their share of the last section,
so that only the undergraduate
share needs now to be pulled up to
the mark. To date they have contributed $73.50. It should be said
that the library staff has nearly
completed collections of $500, but
as a part of this was drawn from
the faculty, it is not credited to
them.

The football situation at Hopkins and the duties of every student
• in regard to supporting the team
were most forcefully described by
Coach Brennick at the mass-meeting held last Friday at 12.30
o'clock in the Civil Engineering
Building. The meeting was but
poorly attended, as have been the
other student gatherings this fall.
Alec Wolfe made note of this in his
opening speech, and after a discussion it was decided to hold subsequent mass-meetings on every Friday at 12.30 o'clock, instead of on
Wednesdays.
This arrangement was decided
upon by a committee composed of
one representative of the Student
Council, one of the Athletic Association and one of the Y. M. C. A.
The majority of those present favored Friday as the suitable day.
The particular point made by
Coach Brennick in his speech was
that since the Secretary of War
favors college sports as a means
to prepare men to meet the physical demands of war, it is no longer
the student's privilege, but it is
his duty to come out for football
or some other form of athletics.
He also said that it would be a
good plan for those who for some
valid reason cannot come out for
the 'Varsity team to practice on
Straus Field, and meet local teams
for the sake of the exercise afforded. Those, however, who are qualified to play on the first team and
have not yet donned the J. H. U.
football uniform should join the
squad at once. And all the other
students, he continued,should support the team by rendering it encouragement from the cheering
section. He concluded by saying
that thought the team was crippled
because of injuries sustained by
several members, he expected to
make a good showing against
Dickinson, provided it received
loyal support.

elected men to fill the vacancies
left by members enlisting in Government service, and chose managers for the lacrosse and baseball
teams at its first meeting of the
year on last Monday. Alec Wolfe,
president of the Association, presided at the fleeting, which was
attended by Dr. Abercrombie,
Harry Corner, graduate manager
of athletics; Dr. "Tom" Brown,
alumni delegate; Jarrett, newlyelected senior delegate; Schmidt
and Carroll, junior delegates; and
Stuart, sophomore delegate.

fill vacancies, it elected D. W.
Burbage vice-president, which office was held by F. Sutton; Beverly Smith, corresponding secretary,
to fill S. Egerton's place; Marion
B. Hopkins, alumni delegate, to
occupy M. Bagley's position; and
Winslow and Jarrett, senior delegates, to supersede Robert Duncan
and E. S. Warner. All these men
are leaders in Hopkins athletics—
Burbage being in charge of cheering; Smith being prominent in
track and Captain Firor's assistalit; Winslow participating in
both football and track; and Jarrett being manager of football.
R. C. Thomsen, '19, was elected
manager of lacrosse, to fill the vacancy left by Clark, now in the
Hopkins ambulance unit, and D.
Coulter,'20, was appointed to take
Randall's place as manager of the
baseball team. Randall is now in
the Maryland field artillery.

permission to the track team to
use the cross-country course, lockers and field house for a crosscountry run of the S. A. I. A. A.

pointed out the unusual chances a
freshman has to make the team
this year.

schedule, which starts off with
the big cross-country meets—the
S. A. I. A. A. meet on Saturday,
November 24,, and the A. A. U.
championships on Thanksgiving

large squad turn out at once for
cross-country work, as it will be

SHIPS AS ENGINEER OFFICERS

A number of the graduates of
the Marine Engineering School
have been placed on ships during
the past week. Two sailed on
Wednesday afternoon on the U. S.
S. Sewanee from New York as junior engineer officers. A number
are now- taking examinations at
the Custom House for licenses as
deck officers.

navigation students are preparing
themselves for a great demand
which is certain to materialize as
the U.S.Shipping Board puts more
of its vessels into service carrying
food and supplies to the Allies and
troops in France. It is considered
that in training officers for this
service the schools at Johns Hopkins University are supplying a
vital necessity.

June 26, 1917.
It is funny that you have only
received one of my letters, for I
wrote again from Paris at the
same time that I sent a number
of picture postcards. I can't send
any picture postal cards from here
as it is against the law to send
pictures of any kind from the war
zone.
We have been fairly busy lately.
About every other night we have
to stay out until morning. In
fact, most of our real work is at
night. If we drive too near the
lines in day time, the German observation balloons can spot us. It
is easy to trace the lines from the
location of the balloons. Both the
French and Gernians have lines
of observation balloons about two
to four miles back from the
trenches. We seldom go closer to
the trenches than the artillery, but
it gets quite hot there at times.
Twice the other night we had to
stop and wait because the Germans were dropping shells at the
bridges and towns ahead of us.
As soon as they slowed up we
went on.
We are getting so used to hearing the big guns and hearing Boche
shells whistle overhead that we
scarcely notice them any more. It
does not seem very dangerous, although no one knows where he
will happen to be when the shell
lands.
